Description

Ayurveda is a traditional system of medicine and health care which originated in the Indian subcontinent. The term Ayurveda denotes "knowledge of life". It is a compound of two words, "ayu" (life) and "veda" (knowledge). The discipline encompasses the physical, psychological, spiritual and social dimensions of life, deals with dynamic concepts of well-being, harmony, health promotion and longevity, and concerns itself with healthy, beneficial and advantageous aspects of human life as well as its unhealthy, deleterious and disadvantageous aspects.

The coalescence of body, sense organs, mind and self that dynamically supports, nourishes and propagates itself despite its eventual disintegration. Ayurveda uses several terms as synonyms for life, based on the different perspectives under which they are understood.
A mode of life that is advantageous for oneself and generally beneficial.
A mode of life that is disadvantageous for oneself and generally detrimental.
A lifestyle characterized by a high quotient of happiness.
A lifestyle characterized by a low quotient of happiness.

Listing multiple conclusions without refuting any of them.

A detailed description of previously listed topics.
An illustrative statement understood only by experts with the specific domain knowledge.

column3: A statement that negates the argument of the opponent.
A brief and incomplete or partial description of an extensive subject.
A statement that clarifies the aims and objectives of a proposed activity or action.
Repetition of a previously cited statement when it acquires relevance in another context.
An arrangement of words and sentences structured and ordered so as to make complete sense.

A statement that allows several discretionary options.
The narration of a topic in the correct logical sequence.
A statement whose meaning suggests the opposite of its ostensible expression.
A statement which develops a subject matter in detail.

The word or part of a sentence which encapsulates the actual meaning.
A conceptual construction, the work of the imagination.
Description used to denote a particular inclination, tendency, or habit. Also refers to methods of diagnosis and treatment.
An exegetical commentary on, or explanation of, Ayurvedic texts.

An established theory that has been critically examined and accepted by qualified investigators. It may be common to all schools of thought, scripture and branches of science (sarvatantrasiddhantah) or particular to any one of them (pratitantrasiddhantah).
A statement which aims to establish authoritative knowledge based on affirmation or refutation of its evidence; in general Sanskrit literature it means a debate/thesis/ proposition/ argument.
Technical rules for an argument or debate.
A statement which has exhausted the scope for further questioning.
A question or query raised to challenge the expressive power and scope of a statement and to clarify any ambiguity.
A statement which is beset with syntactical defects and requires clarification.
Unconditional acceptance of different positions, including those which are inconclusive.
A statement whose derived meaning allows for another interpretation.

column2: Varying meaning or shifting the topic
column3: A statement that is not relevant or applicable to its context.
The response or reply to a challenge or objection.
Applying the logic of the proposed example to arrive at a definite conclusion.
Arguing with the sole intention of finding fault with an opponent's statement.
A specious and verbose statement made with the sole intention of unnerving the opponent.
A debate in which the speaker resorts to quibbling and illegitimate commentary to argue their own case and refute that of their opponent.
The desire to explore and investigate a particular topic out of curiosity and with the intention of knowing the truth.
A discussion among experts in the field in the manner of a peer-review.
A deduction or conclusive statement; the final step of inference when affirming a proposed hypothesis.
Behaviour indicating that the opponent has reached the end of their argument and can no longer defend the stated viewpoint.
Correction of faults or defects revealed in a previous statement.
A statement requiring proof; the first step in the logical or inferential process of proving a hypothesis.
A shift from the original hypothesis, rejection of an initial statement in response to an opponent's views.
Offering a meaning or interpretation contrary to that of the proposed hypothesis.
An enquiry or cross-examination based on sequential questions.
A statement deficient in any of the five components of a sentence, thereby resulting in incomplete or distorted expression of meaning.
A statement free of any syntactical deficiencies and congruent with its exactly intended meaning.
A debate in which no counter-thesis is affirmed, and views are refuted without objective examination.
Arriving at a clear and unambiguous decision.
Justifying a proposition based on sound reason, illustration and conclusion.
Proposing a fallacious or irrelevant form of reasoning in a given context.
Discussion and debate between peers which is conducted in a friendly spirit and serves to advance knowledge.
The standard of examination which affirms valid knowledge.
Valid knowledge.

column2: Proof, means of valid cognition or knowledge
column3: The tools which lead to accurate, true knowledge in Ayurveda are direct perception, observation (pratyakṣham), codified knowledge, expert opinion (aptopadesha), inference based on observations (anumana), reasoning, understanding causation (yukti) and analogy (upamana).
The immediate form of cognition arising from the interaction of the five senses and objects in the world.
The process in which the object of cognitive organ(s) (indriyartha), cognitive organ (indriya), mind (manas) and soul (atma) acquire direct perception of an object.
Direct perception, observation without specific details of the cognitive process.
Direct perception, observation with specific details of the cognitive process.
The process of inference, in which a new conclusion is reached from direct observation by applying reason.
A conclusion reached from stated premises.
An argument which appears to be fallacious.
A cause or reason; the immediate cause of an observable event; the pivotal element in the inferential process.
A cause possessing all formal characteristics which allow it to act as a sufficient reason for the inference of its marked object; the independent variable influencing the dependent variable.
Another term for the independent variable.
The effect or dependent variable influenced by the independent variable.
A fallacious inference which renders the entire inferential process invalid.

The level of sensitivity between cause (hetu) and sign (linga). When the sign is invariably present with the cause (when the symptom is always seen associated with the pathological condition), this is referred to as invariable concomitance or sensitivity.

The level of specificity between cause (hetu) and sign (linga). When the sign is coterminous with the cause and no other entity (when the symptom is seen only with a particular pathological condition) this is referred to as non-deviation or specificity.
What is inseparable, inherent and essentially unified, e.g. an organic body.
The chance effect by which a medicine appears to cure or relieve the symptoms of a disease, when it is not possible to confirm a clinical outcome is the result of a given course of action.
The real and attributable effect of a medicine or treatment, when it is possible to confirm that a clinical outcome is the result of a given course of action.
Relating to or depending on special qualities, limited by particular conditions, valid only under certain suppositions.
A type of inference in which perception is obtained by negative concomitance (erroneous congruence between two premises).
A type of inference in which perception is obtained by positive concomitance (veridical congruence between two premises).
A method of speculative reasoning or debate.
Obtaining the proof of inference for oneself.
Obtaining the proof of inference for others.

column2: Improper reason appearing identical to the subject
column3: Improper reasoning while making an inference in a particular context; a fallacy of inference; one of the ahetu.
The process of drawing an inference based on an analogy.
The context in which a cause-and-effect relationship has not been affirmed but is being examined or investigated.

column2: Context in which a cause-and-effect relationship is affirmed
column3: Figuratively, an accommodating context or environment.

column2: Context in which a cause-and-effect relationship is negated
column3: Figuratively, an adversarial context or environment.
A condition pertaining to the logical conditions of inference in which minor terms uniformly exist in the same loci as major terms.
A condition pertaining to the logical conditions of inference in which minor terms do not exist in all loci with major terms.

A collective term used for deriving intended inference based on five syllogistic steps, namely: proposition/declaration (pratijna), means/reason or cause for obtaining knowledge (hetu), example (drishtanta/audaharana), comparison between proposition and example (upanaya) and establishment of the statement (nigamana).
An illustration or example which can be understood by both expert and lay person.

The agent which initiates action independently; also denoted as cause (hetu) or doer (karma). It may be of three types: inherent cause (samavayikarana), non-inherent cause (asamavayi-karana) and efficient cause (nimitta-karana).
Of the three types of cause (karana), inherent cause is the most essential: it denotes the causal substrate or substance in which an effect occurs (through inherence).

This type of cause includes only qualities (including relational qualities) that inhere in the causal substrate and are causally relevant to the effect, e.g. coloured threads in the appearance of a piece of cloth.

This type of cause includes all other factors that are causally relevant to the effect in question. A potter, along with his wheel, rod and tools can be regarded as the "efficient" cause of the effect, a pot. This resembles the cause of the same name in Aristotelianism.
Statement of an authority or expert in a particular field.
The perception of the multiplicity of factors behind a phenomenon or event.
A Sanskrit term which literally means "comparison"; the fourth of the five means (pramaṇa) by which valid cognition of the world is possible.

column2: Object of knowledge, the object of investigation
column3: The objects of enquiry in any given discipline or field.
Etymologically "the meaning or referent of a word", it is applied to any entity that is knowable and nameable, i.e. an object of experience.

column2: Six ontological categories of an object
column3: The object of experience is subdivided into six fundamental categories: generality (samanyam), particularity (vishesham), substance (dravyam), quality (gunah), action (karma), and inherence (samavayaḥ).
Denotes the universal or class-essence. The principle of similarity may identify a commonality among different substances, qualities and actions.

column2: Similarity at the level of substance
column3: Substance is the substratum of qualities and actions and the material cause of all composite things. This term denotes the similarity between substances, e.g. flesh to replenish and nourish muscle tissue.

column2: Similarity at the level of qualities or properties
column3: Quality exists in substance. This term denotes the similarity in quality exhibited by different substances, e.g. semen and milk.

column2: Similarity at the level of action
column3: Action or physical movement which may lead to an increase in a specific element. e.g. sleep increasing kapha.
The unique individuality of the substances. An attribute that causes depletion or decrease (hrasahetu), as well as diversity and dissimilarity (prthaktva).

column2: Dissimilarity at the level of substance
column3: A substance which on consumption or usage may lead to a decrease in a specific element or attribute in the living system.

column2: Dissimilarity at the level of quality
column3: Qualities with opposing actions which result in one of them being depleted, e.g. the pacification of vata with usage of sesame oil owing to its opposite qualities.

column2: Dissimilarity at the level of action
column3: An activity which causes depletion or reduction, e.g. physical exercise reducing kapha, which otherwise would increase with inactivity.
Matter.

A group of nine elementary causal substances that underlie the manifestation of all other substances, namely five basic elements (space, air, fire, water and earth), self (atma), mind (manas), time (kala) and direction (dik).
The five elements (panchamahabhuta) 1. Space (akasha); 2. air (vayu); 3. fire (tejas, agni); 4. water (jalam); and 5. earth (prithvi).
Characterized by non-obstruction and responsible for the space occupied by all substances. It is the substratum of sound, perceived by the ears.
Responsible for movement, acts as the substratum of touch perceived by skin.
Responsible for heat, acts as the substratum for form and vision, perceived by the eyes.
Responsible for cohesion and fluidity, acts as the substratum of taste, perceived by the tongue.
Responsible for mass and the force of attraction. It acts as the substratum of smell, perceived by the nose.
Subtle physical state of all five elements from which a gross element (mahabhuta) is produced.
Soul, the principle of life and sensation, the individual self, the conscious element in the human body.
The soul in association with the living body, the vital principle as the proximate cause of life and action.
The lifelong vital principle.
Perceiver of knowledge, soul.
A word which also denotes soul, but may be used figuratively to denote author or physician.
The soul (atma) not actively participating in any action but performing the duty of a witness.
Relating to the soul as the presiding entity over the body.
The subtle body which consists of mind or psyche (manas), sense organs (indriya) and soul (atma) and is devoid of gross body; it is sometimes referred as the causal body or subtle body.
The personal and animating principle in all sentient beings, the soul.
Absolute autonomy, not subject to control by others.

column2: Person as the object of treatment
column3: The treatable entity (a person), consisting of five elements and soul.

A body composed of 24 elements, namely: 1. eight primordial entities (ashtaprakriti) including unmanifested microcosm (avyakta), all-pervading intelligence (mahat) and the five rudimentary, undifferentiated elements (tanmatra); and 2. sixteen derivatives (shodashavikriti) comprising the five elements, the five organs of sense, five organs of action, and mind.
Not experienced, unobserved, unknown, the invisible result of works done in former states of embodied existence; unseen consequences of an act.
Inactiveness of atma, indicating its principal quality of performing the duty of being a witness to events.
Being everywhere, all pervading, an attribute of atma.
A process or state whose beginning cannot be ascertained.
Awareness, conscious self or intelligence.
Everlasting, interminable, constant.
A quality of soul which is devoid of all bodily and psychological ailments.
The ability to become irresistible, the condition of not being subject to another's will.
Not liable to change; imperishable, undecaying.
Synonym of the term atma.
Autonomy; an attribute of soul (atma).
Living beings with internal consciousness, i.e. their consciousness is not externally manifested (plants).
Liberation, cessation from worldly existence or transmigration, the fourth goal of life (puruṣartha).
State of self-realization of ultimate reality, which eliminates all worldly miseries and leads to liberation and the emergence of true knowledge in which the soul transcends the ego.
Attaining emancipation or salvation while still alive, liberation from karmic rebirth.

column2: Person showing signs of impending death
column3: A person with fatal prognostic signs.
Having died, after death, in the next world.
The faculty through which cognitive organs (indriya) connect with the soul (atman). Denotes consciousness.
Two features of mind (manas): minuteness (the smallest possible structure) (anutva) and oneness or singularity (ekatva).
Having the dimension of an atom, the smallest possible or minute entity (cf. atomism).
Oneness or singularity (monism), in which no other entity can supplant the role of mind or psyche (manas) in the body.
The rapid conjugation of mind with the sensory or motor organs.
Not everlasting, transient, occasional, incidental.
Mind or psychic functions, namely: thought, analysis, contemplation, mediation and volition.
The process of weighing up or considering the worth of an action or its alternatives.
The application of reason in critical analysis.
The process of speculating about the possible or likely occurrence of an event.
The act of meditating or contemplating a chosen object, a form of focused thinking in which mind and body function as a harmonious whole.
The process of assessing merits and demerits.
The characteristic features or attributes of the mind.
Understanding, intelligence or wisdom.
The controlling or stable intellect, the ability to restrain or resolve impulsive behaviour.
The faculty of recollection, remembrance of things directly perceived or heard (scriptures) which results from a particular conjunction between soul and mind.
Six mental attributes or inner faults that lead to bondage of the soul, namely: desire, anger, greed, delusion, arrogance and jealousy.
Lust or desire for sensual pleasure; also, one of the four goals of life (puruṣartha).
Also translated as fury, rage or wrath.
An excessive or insatiable desire to acquire an object beyond need.
A state of confusion or perplexity that leads to incorrect perception and error.
A state of being emotionally aroused, prideful and stubborn.
A state of being discontent with one's state of affairs, being envious, competitive.
A term for ego in the possessive or prideful sense; also, a principle in the cosmic development of individuality or self- consciousness.
A term that expresses self-command or self-control.
A natural attachment, inclination or fondness for something; often used as a synonym for faith or love.
A term that expresses modesty, sense of decency or decorum.
A term that expresses proper conduct, decency, modesty or mildness.
The ability to distinguish and classify things according to their absolute properties.
A state of affliction caused by various determinants (vibhava) such as the death of a loved person, loss of wealth or personal misfortune.
A mental state characterized by infatuation or being led astray.
A state of mind unaffected by greed, freedom from undue desire, disinterestedness.
A condition of arrogance, haughtiness, insolence or conceit.
The four-tiered inner system: intellect (buddhi), mind (manas), self-awareness (ahamkara) and the storehouse of moods and memories (citta) which facilitate perception, cognition and consciousness.
Time as a continuum, one of the nine elementary causal substances (karanadravya).
The points of the compass, cardinal and ordinal directions, bearing points.
An entity that has not settled into any fixed shape or form, and is not embodied.
A tangible or perceptible substance, or substance that has settled into a fixed shape or form; also refers to material, or incarnate things.
An applicable or effective substance that is a manifestation of the nine causal substances.
Any living, sentient, aware, feeling, animate being; any substance imbued with life (including plants).
A division of the natural world which refers to living beings which have internal awareness or inner sentience not manifested externally, i.e. trees and plants.
A plant which does not bear visible flowers (apushpa) such as the flowerless Ficus glomerata (udumbara) or Ficus benghalensis (vaṭa).
A plant which bears visible flowers and fruits such as Mangifera indica (amra) or Syzyigium cumini (jambu).
A tree, e.g. Indian banyan (Ficus benghalensis L.) (vata).
A herb or shrub, e.g. country mallow (Sida cordifolia L.) (bala).
A twiner or climber, e.g. vidari (Pueraria tuberosa) or kapikacchu (Mucuna prurita).
A small, nonclimbing plant, e.g. Abutilon indicum (atibala) or Desmodium gangeticum (shaliparni).

column2: A plant which withers after fructification
column3: A plant which perishes after bearing fruit or being harvested such as annual herbs like paddy, pulses, wheat or maize.

column2: Mobile life form with internal and external sentience
column3: Any living being in the animal kingdom which visibly reacts to external stimuli.
An animal species which undergoes placental birth, e.g. humans, lions, tigers, cows or goats.
An animal species which undergoes oviparous birth, e.g. reptiles, birds or fish.
An insect species which thrives in a sweaty or humid environment e.g. flies, mosquitos, ants or worms.
Smaller creatures which sprout from the earth or dwell underneath mud, e.g. frogs.
A non-living, inanimate substance lacking all consciousness, e.g. minerals.
An inorganic substance naturally occurring in the earth which has a consistent and distinctive set of physical properties and composition; a mineral.
Any artificial or synthesized substance.

Attribute, property or quality of a substance; it forms an inseparable entity with substance (dravya); quality is devoid of any action on its own, although it is responsible for action through dravya.

column2: Three primordial psychophysical attributes of nature
column3: The three primary attributes of the universe, also indicative of mental attributes: tranquillity or harmony (sattva), agitation or activity (rajas) and inertia (tamas). The interplay of these guṇas defines the character of a person or thing and determines the progress of life.
Characterized by lightness, knowledge and enlightenment, it is a stable state of mind and does not vitiate the same.
Characterized by activity, initiation, action and attachment, it is capable of vitiating the mind.
Characterized by darkness, ignorance and laziness, it is capable of vitiating the mind.
The five objects of sensory perception: touch, smell, sight, taste and sound.
Trait of earth element.
Trait of water element.
Trait of fire element.
Trait of air element.
Trait of space element.
The property of a substance which is related to body tissues; it is extensively used for selecting and preparing Ayurveda medicines and applying them successfully.
The quality of a substance which is responsible for nourishment.
The quality of a substance which promotes lightness and decreases physical bulk and heaviness.
The quality of a substance which is responsible for slow, mild or low intensity activity or response.
The quality of a substance which is responsible for rapid, strong or high intensity activity or response.
The quality of a substance which is responsible for promoting coldness and stiffness (stambhana).
The quality of a substance which is responsible for promoting sweating, softening or ripening (paka).
The quality of a substance which is responsible for imparting smoothness, oiliness and moisture.
The quality of a substance which is responsible for dryness and absorbs moisture.
The quality of a substance which is responsible for smoothness.
The quality of a substance which is responsible for roughness.
The quality of a substance which is responsible for density.
The quality of a substance which is responsible for fluidity.
The quality of a substance which is responsible for producing softness or fragility.
The quality of a substance which is responsible for firmness or hardness.
The quality of a substance which is responsible for minuteness and consequent ability to pass through barriers.
The quality of a substance which is responsible for bulkiness and consequent ability to fill spaces.
The quality of a substance which is responsible for maintaining stability and position.
The quality of a substance which is responsible for stimulation and mobility (prerana), and which governs normal movements such as peristalsis.
The quality of a substance which is responsible for purging and keeping tissues free of vitiated substances.
The quality of a substance which is responsible for providing a coating effect to body tissues.
The six attributes of the self (atma): intelligence (buddhi), pleasure (sukha), sorrow (duhkha), desire (iccha), aversion (dvesha) and effort (prayatna).
The power of forming and retaining concepts and general notions: intelligence, reason, intellect, discernment or judgement.
A favourable perception including happiness, delight, joy and pleasure.
An unfavourable perception including unhappiness, sorrow and grief; the opposite of pleasure.
The direct cause of action that seeks pleasure.
The opposite of desire. The Sanskrit term dvesha, also denotes a suppressible urge.
The quality of being stimulated or striving to achieve an object.
A group of ten clinical decision criteria commencing with "paratva that support a practitioner in the analytical process of deciding on appropriate interventions.
Priority, superiority or greater utility of a substance over the other substances, e.g. in pharmaceutical preparations.

column2: Relatively inferior, further from the cause
column3: Inferiority of substance in relation to other substances.
The quality that enables determination of amounts and calculations.
A combination or amalgam of two or more substances.
The quality of being able to divide or subdivide a particular substance.
The quality by which one substance is differentiated or separated from the other.
The quality by which the measurement of various substances is possible.
The quality of being able to intelligently consider circumstances and act on that basis; also considered as one of the methods of investigation and examination.
The quality of being able to induce a change or transformation in the original properties of any substance.
The quality of being able to repeat an action or procedure to acquire expertise, as exemplified by the saying "practice makes perfect": an important quality for physicians and pharmacists.
Activity, one of the six ontological categories of an object. It refers to pharmacological, nutritional and action in the context of medical practice.
Coexistence or concomitance, an intimate and constant relation between the whole and its parts or the basic elements (mahabhuta) and their qualities.
Absence, negation or nonexistence: there are four kinds.
Antecedent nonbeing of an entity before its production or manifestation.
An entity that ceases to exist after its destruction.
Absolute nonexistence, without beginning or end.

Nonexistence of a substance in the form of another substance. It refers to the difference of one thing from another thing. e.g. a table is not the chair, denoting the mutual exclusiveness of table and chair and the independent existence of one with respect to the existence or non-existence of the other.
The three principal texts of Ayurveda. Carakasamhita, Sushrutasamhita and the writings of Vāgbhaṭa: Ashtangasamgraha and Ashtangahridaya.
The supportive texts of Ayurveda. Madhavanidana, Sharangadharasamhita and Bhavaprakāśa.
A glossary setting out synonyms, as well as the properties, names and actions of drugs, plants, minerals or other substances administered either as food or medicines to the human body.

Ten important aspects of medical examination: principal agent (karana); tool, instrument (karana); substratum of treatment (karyayoni); treatment protocol (karya); immediate outcome, primary endpoint (karyaphala); consequence, long-term effect (anubandha); habitat (desha); time (kala); action (pravritti); and ailment-countering stratagem, means of action (upaya).

column3: The means by which an action is effectuated, the idea expressed by instrumental cause: in the medical context may often refer to the physician, who is instrumental in maintaining fundamental bodily equilibrium.
The tool or instrument used for treatment, i.e. a medicine or procedure.
The intimate cause of illness, i.e. a disturbance of the fundamental bodily equilibrium.
The process undertaken to attain health or the fundamental bodily equilibrium (dhatusamya), i.e. the treatment process.
The aim of treatment: to bring mind, intellect, the sense organs and the body into equilibrium and attain a state of healthiness or happiness.
Continuity of effect or long-term outcome, which includes the achievement of healthy longevity.
Land, habitat or environment; it may designate body parts as well as geographical regions.
Time in general including the seasons, the point when something occurs (which may refer to diseases).
The onset of a treatment or therapeutic action.
A word meaning excellence, goodness or skilfulness: it is often applied to the physician and the justness of any chosen therapy or means of action.
The ability to make correct and rapid decisions under pressing conditions.
These four components or elements are: the physician (vaidya, bhishak), materials for treatment (dravya), attendants or paramedics (upasthata) and the patient (rogi).

The physician or medical practitioner is expected to have the following qualities: to be an expert in medical treatment (daksha), academically qualified (trirthashastrartha), experienced (drishtakarma), in good physical and mental health (shuci) and able to fully appreciate the state of health or illness of the patient.

The material employed for treatment is expected to have the following qualities: utility in various dosage forms (bahukalpa), multitude of therapeutic qualities (bahuguna), wholesome nature (sampanna) and applicable in various contexts (yogyam).
An attendant or paramedic is expected to have the following qualities: to be kind-hearted (anurakta), pure in mind, thoughts and action (shuci), skilled (daksha) and intelligent (buddhiman).

A patient is expected to have the following qualities: to be able to afford treatment personally or through a system support (adhya), consenting (bishagvashya), bear in mind instructions personally or through a reminder system (jnapakah) and exert willpower (satvavan).

The regulatory functional factors of the body formed by the synchronized interplay between the five basic elements within any living system.
The three regulatory functional factors of the body are: vata, pitta and kapha.

column2: Vata, dosha regulating movement and cognition
column3: One of the three regulatory functional factors (dosha). The functional balance governing all sensory perceptions, motor activities and higher mental activities. The predominant basic elements in vata are air and space.

column2: Vata, dosha that provides the attribute of life to an organism, life force
column3: Subtype of vata seated in the head and controlling the intellect, heart, sensory and motor organs and mind. It also regulates activities such as respiration, spitting, sneezing, belching and swallowing. Also denotes life or vitality, which is evidenced by breathing and all kinds of movements relating to the living body.
Subtype of vata seated in the chest region which extends from the umbilical region to the neck or throat. Its functions include effort, strength, governing the voice and speech production.

Subtype of vata seated in the cardiac region (hṛdaya), which circulates or diffuses through the body. It performs the function of circulating of fluids through heart to all parts of the body, as well as transporting various materials from one body part to another.
Subtype of vata seated at the navel (between stomach and intestines) and close to digestive fire: it is responsible for metabolism and transformation.
Subtype of vata seated in the pelvic region and its vicinity. It exerts a downward force. It controls functions like defecation, micturition, parturition, menstruation and ejaculation.
Pitta is one of the three regulatory functional factors; it is responsible for digestion and metabolism in the body. The predominant basic elements in pitta are fire and water.

column2: Pitta, dosha regulating body temperature and metabolic activities
column3: One of the three regulatory functional factors; it is responsible for digestion and metabolism in the body. The predominant basic elements in pitta are fire and water.
Subtype of pitta mainly responsible for digestion. It divides the food into nutritive and waste portions and supports other subtypes of pitta.
Subtype of pitta seated in liver, spleen and its pigment in blood.
Subtype of pitta seated in the eye which is responsible for visual perception.
Subtype of pitta seated in the skin which is responsible for its glossiness or lustre.
Subtype of pitta seated in the heart which is responsible for driving the higher mental functions involving decisions and actions for accomplishments.
General term for functions of pitta
One of the three regulatory functional factors responsible for stability, unctuousness, lubrication, immunity and cohesion. The predominant basic elements in kapha are earth and water.
Subtype of kapha seated in the chest region which supports and sustains the heart and other sites of kapha.
Subtype of kapha seated in the stomach which helps to moisten and loosen food particles and thus aid digestion.
Subtype of kapha seated in the tongue which assists with the perception of taste.
Subtype of kapha seated in the head which nourishes the sensory organs.
Subtype of kapha seated in the joints which provides lubrication.
A combined term for the functions of kapha such as physical and mental strength, forgiveness.
A normal function of kapha. It signifies forbearance, forgiveness and resistance.
A normal function of kapha. It signifies hardness, fixedness, stability and strength.

The seven fundamental structural components of the body, which are formed from digested food. They provide nourishment and support to the body. They are primary circulating nutrient fluid (rasa), blood (rakta), muscle (mamsa), fat (medas), bone (asthi), bone marrow (majja) and semen (sukra). The Sanskrit term dhatu also denotes group of metallic ingredients for medicinal usage.

The second of the seven fundamental structural components. Its function is to give life. It is formed in the liver and spleen with the help of colouring pitta and its metabolic component and receives its name from the red colour.
One of the functions of blood is to give, quicken and vivify life.
One of the functions of primary circulating nutrient fluid.

The fourth of the seven fundamental structural components. Its function is to provide oleation. It refers to adipose tissue and other lipids in the body.

A theory to explain the nourishment of fundamental structural components: it states that primary circulating nutrient fluid (primary product of digestion) is supplied to all seven structural components through channels for their nourishment, just as tributary canals subdivide and distribute irrigation water to every part of a paddy field.

A theory to explain the process of nourishment of fundamental structural components: it states that each structural component selectively absorbs its specific nutrients just as a pigeon picks grains from a granary according to its need.

During the first and initial stage of digestion in the gastrointestinal tract the ingested food is transformed to a predominantly sweet state. This results in the generation of kapha-dosha.
During the second and intermediate stage of digestion in the gastrointestinal tract the ingested food is transformed to a predominantly sour state. This results in the generation of pitta-dosha.
During the third and final stage of digestion in the gastrointestinal tract the ingested food is transformed to a predominantly pungent state. This results in the generation of vata-dosha.

An individual's inherent nature is the discrete phenotype of an individual based on physical, psychological, physiological and behavioural traits, independently of social, ethnic and geographical variables.

It represents a person's baseline state of optimal functioning of both body and mind. The predominant expression of an individual's inherent nature in bodily functions is known as body constitution with a predominance of dosha (doshaprakrti) and its expression in the domains of mental and physical personality is called kaya/manasaprakriti. However, for all practical purposes the doshaprakriti and kaya of an individual need to be interpreted in consideration with the following entities: ethnicity (jaati), familial inheritance, genetics (kula), the influence of a specific geographical region and climate (desha), as well as the ageing process (kala).
